section.name: s56
section.heading: Protection of stairways and lifts in accommodation and service spaces

subsection.leadIn: All stairways shall be of steel frame construction, except where the Director may approve the use of other material which he is satisfied is equally effective, and shall be within enclosures formed of “A” Class divisions, except that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a stairway connecting only 2 decks need not be enclosed on both decks provided that the integrity of the deck is maintained by adequate bulkheads or doors at one between-deck space. When a stairway is closed at one between-deck space, the stairway enclosure shall have the same integrity standards as is required by the Tables at the end of regulation 55 for the deck which separates the between-deck spaces; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: stairways may be fitted in the open in a public space, provided that they lie wholly within such public space.

subsection.content: Every opening in a stairway enclosure shall be provided with a means of closure which shall be permanently attached thereto.

Every stairway enclosure shall have direct communication with the corridors and be of sufficient area to prevent congestion, having regard to the number of persons likely to use them in an emergency. In so far as practicable, stairway enclosures shall not give direct access to cabins, service lockers, or other enclosed spaces containing combustibles in which a fire is likely to originate.

subsection.name: 3A
subsection.leadIn: All stairway enclosures shall comply with the following requirements not later than 1 October 1997—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: only public toilets, lifts, lockers of non-combustible materials providing storage of safety equipment and open information counters may be located within the stairway enclosure boundaries;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.leadIn: other existing spaces within the stairway enclosure shall be— (E.R. 3 of 2022)

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: emptied, permanently closed and disconnected from the electrical system; or

subparagraph.name: B
iii
subparagraph.content: the spaces described in subparagraph (ii) may have direct access to stairway enclosures by the provision of “A” Class doors in accordance with regulation 55, and subject to a sprinkler system being provided in these spaces. However, cabins shall not directly open into the stairway enclosure;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: spaces other than public spaces, corridors, public toilets, special category spaces, other stairways required by regulation 128(2)(c), open deck spaces and spaces covered by paragraph (a)(ii) are not permitted to have direct access to stairway enclosures;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: existing machinery spaces of category (10) described in regulation 55(3)(b) and existing back offices for information counters which open directly into the stairway enclosure may be retained, provided that they are protected by smoke detectors and that back offices for information counters contain only furniture of restricted fire risk;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: furniture in stairway enclosures shall be limited to seating. It shall be fixed, limited to six seats on each deck in each stairway enclosure, be of restricted fire risk, and shall not restrict the passenger escape route. The Director may permit additional seating in the main reception area within stairway enclosures, if it is fixed, non-combustible, and does not restrict the passenger escape route. Furniture shall not be permitted in passenger and crew corridors forming escape routes in cabin areas. In addition to the above, lockers of non-combustible material, providing storage for safety equipment required by regulations, may be permitted. (L.N. 414 of 1995; E.R. 3 of 2022)

subsection.content: Every lift trunk shall be so fitted as to prevent the passage of smoke and flame from one between-deck to another and shall be provided with means of closing so as to permit the control of draught and smoke.

Where an “A” Class division is pierced for the passage of electric cables, pipes, trunks, girders, beams or for other purposes, the arrangements shall be such that the effectiveness of the division in resisting fire is not thereby impaired except as provided in subregulation (7).

Where, of necessity, a ventilation duct passes through a main vertical zone bulkhead, a fail-safe automatic closing fire damper shall be fitted adjacent to the bulkhead. The damper shall also be capable of being manually closed from each side of the bulkhead. The operating positions shall be readily accessible and be marked in red light-reflecting colour. The duct between the bulkhead and the damper shall be of steel or other equivalent material and, if necessary, be insulated to a standard to comply with subregulation (1). The damper shall be fitted with a visible indicator at each operating position showing whether the damper is in the open or shut position.

Except for hatches between special category spaces within a single horizontal zone, or between cargo spaces or stores or baggage spaces, and between such spaces and the weather decks, every opening shall be provided with permanently attached means of closing which shall be at least as effective for resisting fire as the division in which it is fitted.

content.leadIn: Every door and door frame in an “A” Class division shall be constructed of steel or other equivalent material and the means of securing it when closed shall provide resistance to fire as well as to the passage of smoke and flame, as far as practicable, equivalent to that of the bulkhead in which the door is situated:
content.proviso: Provided that a watertight door shall not be required to be insulated.

subsection.content: Any door in such a division shall be so constructed that it can be opened and closed by one person from either side of the division.

Every door in a division constructed in compliance with regulations 53(1) and 56(1), except a watertight door or one which is normally locked, shall be self-closing and capable of closing against an adverse inclination of up to 3 1/2o. The speed of door closure shall be controlled so as to prevent undue danger to personnel. All such doors which are held in the open position shall be capable of release from a central control station, either simultaneously or in groups, and also individually from a position at the door. The release mechanism shall be so designed that the door will automatically close in the event of disruption of the control system; except that this requirement shall not apply to a watertight door. Hold-back hooks, not subject to central control station release, are not permitted. (L.N. 414 of 1995)

subsection.name: 6A
subsection.content: Hinged fire doors in stairway enclosures, main vertical zone bulkheads and galley boundaries which are normally kept open shall be self-closing and be capable of release from a central control station and from a position at the door not later than 1 October 1997. (L.N. 414 of 1995)

subsection.name: 6B
subsection.content: All fire doors, other than hinged fire doors, in stairway enclosures, main vertical zone bulkheads and galley boundaries which are normally kept open shall be capable of release from a central control station and from a position at the door not later than 1 October 2000. (L.N. 414 of 1995)

subsection.name: 6C
subsection.content: A panel shall be placed in a continuously manned central control station, not later than 1 October 1997, to indicate whether the fire doors on stairway enclosures, main vertical zone bulkheads and galley boundaries are closed. (L.N. 414 of 1995)

Where a space is protected by an automatic sprinkler system complying with the provisions of Schedule 11 to the Merchant Shipping (Safety) (Fire Appliances) (Ships Built On or After 25 May 1980 but Before 1 September 1984) Regulations (Cap. 369 sub. leg. X), or fitted with a continuous “B” Class ceiling, the closing of openings in decks not forming steps in main vertical zones nor bounding horizontal zones shall be reasonably tight and such decks shall meet the “A” Class integrity requirements in so far as is reasonable and practicable in the opinion of the Director. (E.R. 3 of 2022)

The requirements for “A” Class integrity of the outer boundaries of a ship shall not apply to glass partitions, windows and sidescuttles, subject to the requirements of regulation 60. The requirements for “A” Class integrity shall not apply to exterior doors in superstructures and deckhouses, except that doors opening on to lifeboat and liferaft handling and embarkation areas shall be of such construction as to protect these areas from a space having a potential fire hazard.

subsection.leadIn: Exhaust ducts from galley ranges where grease or fat is likely to accumulate and which pass through accommodation spaces or spaces containing combustible materials shall comply with the following requirements not later than 1 October 1997—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: such ducts shall be constructed of “A” Class divisions; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: each duct shall be fitted with—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a grease trap readily removable for cleaning, unless an alternative grease removal process is fitted;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a fire damper located in the lower end of the duct;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: arrangements operable from within the galley for shutting off the exhaust fans;

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: fixed means for extinguishing a fire within the duct; and

subparagraph.name: v
subparagraph.content: suitably located hatches for inspection and cleaning. (L.N. 414 of 1995)

subsection.content: Where a “B” Class division is pierced for the passage of electric cables, pipes, trunks, girders, beams or for other purposes, the arrangements shall be such that the effectiveness of the division in resisting fire is not thereby impaired except as provided in subregulation (4).

Doors and door frames in “B” Class divisions and means of securing them shall provide a method of closure which shall have resistance to fire as far as practicable equivalent to the division, except that ventilation openings may be permitted in the lower portion of such doors. Where such opening is in or under a door, the total net area of any such opening or openings shall not exceed 0.05 square metre. When such opening is cut in a door, it shall be fitted with a grille made of steel. Doors shall be non-combustible.

The requirements for “B” Class integrity of the outer boundaries of a ship shall not apply to glass partitions, windows and sidescuttles. The requirements for “B” Class integrity shall not apply to exterior doors in superstructures and deckhouses.

subsection.leadIn: Where an automatic sprinkler system complying with the provisions of Schedule 11 to the Merchant Shipping (Safety) (Fire Appliances) (Ships Built On or After 25 May 1980 but Before 1 September 1984) Regulations (Cap. 369 sub. leg. X), is fitted— (E.R. 3 of 2022)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the closing of openings in decks need only meet the “B” Class integrity requirements in so far as is reasonable and practicable; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: openings in corridor bulkheads of “B” Class materials shall be protected in accordance with the provisions of regulation 54.

subsection.content: Wherever practicable the system of ducts leading from each ventilating fan shall be within one main vertical or horizontal zone.

Where ventilation systems penetrate decks, precautions shall be taken, in addition to those relating to the fire integrity of the decks required by regulation 57, to reduce the likelihood of smoke and hot gases passing from one between-deck space to another through the system. In addition to insulation requirements contained in this regulation, vertical ducts shall, if necessary, be insulated as required by Table 1, Table 2, Table 3 or Table 4 of regulation 55.
The main inlets of every air supply system and the main outlets of every air exhaust system shall be capable of being closed from external positions.
Ducts serving a stairway enclosure shall be taken from the fan room independently of other ducts in the ventilation system and shall not serve any other space.

All power ventilation, except machinery and cargo space ventilation and any alternative system which may be required under subregulation (6), shall be fitted with controls so grouped that all fans may be stopped from either of 2 separate positions which shall be situated as far apart as practicable. Controls provided for the power ventilation serving machinery spaces shall be so grouped as to be operable from 2 positions, one of which shall be outside such spaces. Fans serving power ventilation systems to cargo spaces shall be capable of being stopped from a safe position outside such spaces.

There shall be provided for every control station situated below deck other than a control station situated in the machinery space, means to ensure ventilation, visibility and freedom from smoke within it so that, in the event of a fire in the ship, the equipment it contains may be operated effectively. Unless the control station is situated on, and has access to, an open deck or is provided with local closing arrangements equally effective to maintain ventilation, visibility and freedom from smoke in the event of a fire in the ship, there shall be provided at least 2 entirely separate means of supplying air to such control stations and the air inlets to these sources of supply shall be so situated that the risk of both drawing in smoke simultaneously is, as far as practicable, eliminated.

subsection.leadIn: Except in cargo spaces, ventilation ducts shall be constructed of the following materials—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: subject to the requirements of paragraph (c) and of subregulations (8) and (9), ducts of less than 0.075 square metres in sectional area shall be constructed of non-combustible materials. Where such ducts penetrate “A” or “B” Class divisions, due regard shall be given to ensuring the fire integrity of the division;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: ducts, not in general exceeding 0.02 square metres in sectional area nor 2 metres in length, need not be non-combustible provided that the following conditions are satisfied—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the duct is constructed of suitable material having regard to the risk of fire;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the duct is used only at the terminal end of the ventilation system; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the duct is not located closer than 0.6 metre along its length to a penetration of an “A” Class division or a “B” Class division.

subsection.leadIn: Ducts provided for the ventilation of machinery spaces of Category A, galleys or car deck spaces shall not pass through accommodation spaces, service spaces or control stations unless either—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the ducts are constructed of steel having a thickness of at least 3 millimetres and 5 millimetres for ducts the widths or diameters of which are up to and including 300 millimetres and 760 millimetres and over respectively and, in the case of such ducts, the widths or diameters of which are between 300 and 760 millimetres having a thickness to be obtained by interpolation; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: are suitably supported and stiffened; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: are fitted with automatic fire dampers close to the boundaries penetrated; and

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: are insulated to “A-60” standard from the machinery space, galley or car deck space to a point at least 5 metres beyond each fire damper; or

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the ducts are constructed, supported and stiffened in accordance with paragraph (a)(i) and (ii); and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: are insulated to “A-60” standard throughout the accommodation spaces, service spaces or control stations,

subsection.continued: except that penetrations of main zone bulkhead or decks shall comply with the requirements of regulation 57.

subsection.leadIn: Ducts providing ventilation to accommodation spaces, service spaces or control stations shall not pass through machinery spaces of Category A, galleys or car deck spaces unless either—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the ducts where they pass through a machinery space of Category A, galley or car deck space are constructed, supported and stiffened in accordance with subregulation (8)(a)(i) and (ii); and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: automatic fire dampers are fitted close to the boundaries penetrated; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: provided the integrity of the machinery space, galley or car deck space boundaries is maintained at the penetrations; or

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the ducts where they pass through a machinery space of Category A, galley or car deck space are constructed, supported and stiffened in accordance with subregulation (8)(a)(i) and (ii); and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: are insulated to “A-60” standard within the machinery space, galley or car deck space,

subsection.continued: except that penetrations of main zone bulkheads and decks shall comply with the requirements of regulation 57.

subsection.leadIn: Exhaust ducts from galley ranges, where they pass through accommodation spaces containing combustible materials, shall be constructed of “A” Class divisions. Every exhaust duct shall be fitted with—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a grease trap readily removable for cleaning;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a fire damper located in the duct at the boundary of the galley;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: arrangements, operable from within the galley, for shutting off the exhaust fan; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a fixed means of extinguishing a fire within the duct.

subsection.leadIn: Where a ventilation duct of sectional are exceeding 0.02 square metre passes through an “A” Class bulkhead or deck, the opening in the bulkhead or deck shall be lined with a steel sheet sleeve unless the duct, where it passes through the bulkhead or deck, is constructed of steel. At the penetration the sleeve or duct shall comply with the following specification—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the duct or sleeve shall have a thickness of at least 3 millimetres over a length of 900 millimetres. When passing through bulkheads this length shall if possible be divided into 450 millimetres on each side of the bulkhead. The duct or sleeve shall be insulated so as to maintain the standard of fire integrity of the deck or bulkhead; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: every duct shall be fitted with a fire damper unless the Director determines otherwise. In every duct of sectional area exceeding 0.075 square metre the fire damper shall operate automatically, but it shall also be capable of being closed manually from each side of the bulkhead or deck. The operating position shall be readily accessible and be marked in red light-reflecting colour. The damper shall be fitted with a visible indicator showing whether the damper is in the open or shut position. Fire dampers are not required, however, where ducts pass through spaces surrounded by “A” Class divisions without serving those spaces, provided those ducts have the same fire integrity and insulation value as the bulkheads which they pierce.

subsection.content: Where a ventilation duct of sectional area exceeding 0.02 square metre passes through a “B” Class bulkhead, the opening shall be lined with a steel sleeve of 900 millimetres in length unless the duct, where it passes through the bulkhead, is constructed of steel. This length shall be divided, if possible, into 450 millimetres on each side of the bulkhead.

Fail-safe automatic closing fire dampers with manual operation from within the enclosure shall, not later than 1 October 2000, be fitted to all ventilation ducts serving both accommodation spaces and service spaces and stairway enclosures where they pierce such enclosures. (L.N. 414 of 1995)

Ventilation ducts passing through a main vertical zone bulkhead without serving spaces on both sides or passing through a stairway enclosure without serving that enclosure shall, not later than 1 October 2000, be fitted with fire dampers unless the ducts are constructed and insulated to “A-60” standard and have no openings within the stairway enclosure or in the trunk on the side which is not directly served. (L.N. 414 of 1995)

All windows and sidescuttles in bulkheads within accommodation and service spaces and control stations other than those to which the provisions of regulations 57(8) and 58(3) apply, shall be constructed so as to preserve the integrity requirements of the type of bulkheads in which they are fitted.

subsection.leadIn: Notwithstanding the requirements of Table 1, Table 2, Table 3 or Table 4 of regulation 55—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: all windows and sidescuttles in bulkheads separating accommodation and service spaces and control stations from weather shall be constructed with frames of steel or other suitable materials. The glass shall be retained by a metal glazing bead or angle; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the fire integrity of windows facing open or enclosed lifeboat and liferaft embarkation areas and of windows situated below such areas in such a position that their failure during a fire would impede the launching of, or embarkation into, lifeboats or liferafts shall be such that any potential fire hazard is kept to a minimum.

subsection.leadIn: Within accommodation spaces, service spaces and control stations the following requirements shall be complied with—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the following surfaces shall be such that a Class 1 or 2 surface spread of flame will not be exceeded—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: exposed surfaces in corridor, stairway enclosures, bulkheads, wall and ceiling linings; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: concealed or inaccessible spaces;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the total volume of combustible facings, mouldings, decorations and veneers shall not exceed a volume equivalent to 2.5 millimetres of veneer on the combined area of walls and ceilings. In the case of ships fitted with an automatic sprinkler system complying with the provisions of Schedule 11 to the Merchant Shipping (Safety) (Fire Appliances) (Ships Built On Or After 25 May 1980 but Before 1 September 1984) Regulations (Cap. 369 sub. leg. X), the above volume may include some combustible material used for the erection of “C” Class divisions; (E.R. 3 of 2022)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: veneers used on surfaces and linings to which paragraph (a) applies shall not have a gross calorific potential exceeding 45 megajoules per square metre of surface area for the thickness used as measured in accordance with the method specified in International Standard ISO 1716-1973 (E); (E.R. 3 of 2022)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: furniture in the corridors and stairway enclosures shall be kept to a minimum;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: primary deck coverings, if applied, shall be of approved material which will not readily ignite, or give rise to toxic or explosive hazards at elevated temperatures;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: waste-paper receptacles shall be constructed of non-combustible materials and with solid sides and bottoms.

subsection.leadIn: Within accommodation spaces, service spaces, control stations and machinery spaces—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: all ceilings, linings, draught stops and insulating materials shall be of non-combustible materials except in respect of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: mail rooms and baggage rooms;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: materials used to insulate refrigerated compartments;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: materials used to insulate valves associated with hot and cold service systems provided that their exposed surfaces are such that a Class 1 or 2 surface spread of flame will not be exceeded; and

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: vapour barriers and adhesives used in conjunction with insulating materials, if their exposed surfaces are such that a Class 1 or 2 surface spread of flame will not be exceeded; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: paints, varnishes and other finishes used on exposed interior surfaces shall not be capable of producing excessive quantities of smoke and toxic products.

subsection.leadIn: The following provisions shall apply to all parts of any ship to which this Part applies—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any pipe which penetrates an “A” Class or “B” Class division shall be of suitable material having regard to the temperature such divisions are required to withstand;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: pipes intended for oil or other flammable liquids shall be of suitable material having regard to the risk of fire; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: overboard scuppers, sanitary discharges or other outlets close to or below the waterline shall not be of a material likely to fail in the event of fire and thereby give rise to a danger of flooding.

subsection.leadIn: The following provisions shall apply to the accommodation spaces, service spaces, and control stations, of any ship to which this Part applies—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: every air space enclosed behind a ceiling, panel or lining, shall be divided by close-fitting draught-stops which shall be spaced not more than 14 metres apart and which shall be closed at each deck; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: every ceiling and lining shall be so constructed as to enable a fire patrol to detect any smoke originating in a concealed or inaccessible space without impairing the efficiency of the fire protection of the ship. The Director may exempt any ship from the requirement of this regulation if he is satisfied that there is no risk of fire originating in such a space.

section.name: s63
section.heading: Automatic sprinkler and fire alarm and fire detection system or automatic fire alarm and fire detection system

subsection.leadIn: In every ship to which this Part applies there shall be installed throughout each separate zone, whether vertical or horizontal, in all accommodation and service spaces and in control stations either—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an automatic sprinkler and fire alarm and fire detection system complying with the requirements specified in Schedule 11 to the Merchant Shipping (Safety) (Fire Appliances) (Ships Built On or After 25 May 1980 but Before 1 September 1984) Regulations (Cap. 369 sub. leg. X) and so arranged to protect all such spaces in the ship; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an automatic fire alarm and fire detection system complying with the requirements specified in Schedule 12 to the Merchant Shipping (Safety) (Fire Appliances) (Ships Built On or After 25 May 1980 but Before 1 September 1984) Regulations (Cap. 369 sub. leg. X) and so arranged to detect the presence or the signs of a fire and its location in any such spaces. (E.R. 3 of 2022)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.leadIn: All accommodation and service spaces, stairway enclosures and corridors shall be equipped with—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a smoke detection and alarm system of an approved type and complying with Schedule 11 to the Merchant Shipping (Safety) (Fire Protection) (Ships Built On or After 1 September 1984) Regulations (Cap. 369 sub. leg. Y) not later than 1 October 1997; provided that such a system need not be fitted in private bathrooms, and spaces having little or no fire risk such as voids and similar spaces; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an automatic sprinkler, fire alarm and fire detection system complying with the requirements of Schedule 7 to the Merchant Shipping (Safety) (Fire Protection) (Ships Built On or After 1 September 1984) Regulations (Cap. 369 sub. leg. Y) or the guidelines developed by the International Maritime Organization for an approved equivalent sprinkler system not later than 1 October 2005 or 15 years after the date of construction of the ship, whichever is later; provided that the automatic sprinkler need not be fitted in private bathrooms, and spaces having little or no fire risk such as voids and similar spaces. (L.N. 414 of 1995; E.R. 3 of 2022)

subsection.name: 1B
subsection.content: For the purposes of subregulation (1A), detectors operated by heat instead of smoke in a system described in that subregulation shall be installed in galleys. (L.N. 414 of 1995)

subsection.leadIn: The Director may exempt any ship from the requirements of this regulation in so far as they apply to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any space which he is satisfied affords no substantial fire risk; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any control station.

subsection.leadIn: The following provisions shall apply to special category spaces, whether above or below the bulkhead deck, of any ship to which this Part applies—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: if normal main vertical zoning is not practicable in special category spaces, equivalent protection shall be obtained in such spaces by horizontal zoning and the provision of an efficient fixed fire-extinguishing system. A horizontal zone for the purpose of this regulation may include special category spaces on more than one deck, provided that the overall height of the zone does not exceed 10 metres;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the requirements of regulations 57 and 59 for maintaining the integrity of vertical zones shall apply to decks and bulkheads forming the boundaries separating horizontal zones from each other and from the remainder of the ship;

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: boundary bulkheads of special category spaces shall be insulated as required for category (11) spaces in Table 1 and the horizontal boundaries as required for category (11) spaces in Table 3 of regulation 55;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: indicators shall be provided on the navigating bridge which shall show when any access fire door in the boundary of a special category space is closed;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: every special category space shall be fitted with a manually operated fixed pressure water-spraying system which complies with the requirements specified in Schedule 8 to the Merchant Shipping (Safety) (Fire Appliances) (Ships Built On or After 25 May 1980 but Before 1 September 1984) Regulations (Cap. 369 sub. leg. X). The Director may permit the use of any other fixed fire-extinguishing system which he is satisfied is equally effective by full-scale tests in conditions simulating a flowing petrol fire in a special category space;

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: an efficient patrol system shall be maintained in special category spaces. In any such space in which the patrol is not maintained by a continuous fire watch at all times during the voyage there shall be provided in that space an automatic fire alarm and fire detection system complying with the requirements of Schedule 12 to the Merchant Shipping (Safety) (Fire Appliances) (Ships Built On or After 25 May 1980 but Before 1 September 1984) Regulations (Cap. 369 sub. leg. X);

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: manual fire alarms shall be provided throughout the special category spaces and one shall be placed close to each exit from such spaces;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: every special category space shall be provided with a ventilation system capable of changing the atmosphere within such spaces at least 10 times per hour based upon the gross volume of the space. The ventilation system shall so be arranged as to prevent stratification of the atmosphere and the formation of gas pockets in such spaces. The ventilation system shall be separate from any other ventilation system and the master shall ensure that it shall be operated at all times when vehicles are in such spaces. Any loss or reduction of the ventilating system capacity shall be indicated on the navigating bridge. The outlet from any exhaust ventilation duct shall be sited in a safe position having regard to possible sources of ignition;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: every special category space shall comply with the requirements of regulations 6, 10 and 87 of the Merchant Shipping (Safety) (Fire Protection) (Ships Built On or After 1 September 1984) Regulations (Cap. 369 sub. leg. Y) not later than 1 October 2000. (L.N. 414 of 1995)

text.b: Additional requirements applicable only to special category spaces above the bulkhead deck

subsection.leadIn: The following provisions shall apply additionally to those in subregulation (1) to special category spaces above the bulkhead deck of any ship to which this Part applies—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to ensure the clearance of water accumulating on the deck or decks following the operation of the fixed pressure water-spraying system, scuppers shall be fitted so as to ensure that such water is rapidly discharged directly overboard;

text.b: Precautions against ignition of flammable vapours

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: electrical equipment, wiring and other equipment capable of igniting flammable vapours shall not be installed less than 450 millimetres above any deck on which vapours may accumulate, provided that electrical equipment and wiring may be installed below such level and within the ventilation trunks if it is essential for the safe operation of the ship provided that the equipment is of a type suitable for use in an explosive petrol vapour and air mixture. Electrical equipment installed more than 450 millimetres above any deck on which vapours may accumulate shall be enclosed and protected to prevent discharge of sparks.

text.b: Additional requirements applicable only to special category spaces below the bulkhead deck

subsection.text: The following provisions shall apply additionally to subregulation (1) to special category spaces below the bulkhead deck of any ship to which this Part applies—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: adequate bilge pumping and drainage facilities shall be provided to ensure the clearance of water from the deck or tank top following the operation of the fixed pressure water-spraying system. Where the capacity of the bilge pumps is insufficient to ensure the clearance of the water, additional bilge pumping capacity shall be provided;

text.b: Precautions against ignition of flammable vapours

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: electrical equipment and wiring within such spaces and in ventilation trunks serving such spaces shall be of a type suitable for use in an explosive petrol vapour and air mixture. Other equipment which may constitute a source of ignition of flammable vapours shall not be fitted.

section.name: s65
section.heading: Protection of cargo spaces, other than special category spaces, intended for the carriage of motor vehicles with fuel in their tanks for their own propulsion
section.text: In every ship to which this Part applies the following provisions shall apply to any cargo space, other than a special category space, containing motor vehicles with fuel in their tanks for their own propulsion—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an automatic fire alarm and fire detection system complying with the requirements specified in Schedule 12 to the Merchant Shipping (Safety) (Fire Appliances) (Ships Built On or After 25 May 1980 but Before 1 September 1984) Regulations (Cap. 369 sub. leg. X) shall be provided;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a fixed gas fire-extinguishing system complying with the requirements specified in Schedule 9 to the Merchant Shipping (Safety) (Fire Appliances) (Ships Built On or After 25 May 1980 but Before 1 September 1984) Regulations (Cap. 369 sub. leg. X) shall be provided;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: every such space shall be provided with a ventilation system capable of changing the atmosphere within such spaces at least 10 times per hour based upon the gross volume of the space. The ventilation system shall be arranged to prevent stratification of the atmosphere and the formation of gas pockets in such spaces. The ventilating system shall be separate from any other ventilation system and the master shall ensure that it shall be operated at all times when vehicles are in such spaces. Any loss or reduction of the ventilation system capacity shall be indicated on the navigating bridge. The outlet from any exhaust ventilation duct shall be sited in a safe position having regard to possible sources of ignition;

text.b: Precautions against ignition of flammable vapours

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: electrical equipment and wiring within such spaces and their exhaust ventilation trunks shall be of a type suitable for use in an explosive petrol vapour and air mixture. Other equipment which may constitute a source of ignition of flammable vapours shall not be fitted;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: every such space shall comply with the requirements of regulations 6, 10 and 88 of the Merchant Shipping (Safety) (Fire Protection) (Ships Built On or After 1 September 1984) Regulations (Cap. 369 sub. leg. Y) not later than 1 October 2000. (L.N. 414 of 1995)

section.name: s66
section.heading: Special arrangement in machinery spaces
section.leadIn: The following provisions shall apply to machinery spaces of any ship to which this Part applies—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the number of openings to machinery spaces shall be the minimum compatible with the proper working of the ship;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the sky-lights to machinery spaces of Category A shall be constructed of steel and their flaps shall be capable of being closed and opened from a suitable position outside the space in the event of fire;

paragraph.name: c
d
e
paragraph.content: doors in the boundaries of machinery spaces of Category A, other than watertight doors, shall be arranged so that the closure of the door will be assured in the event of fire in the space. The doors shall be provided with closing arrangements which either comply with regulation 57(6) or are provided with power operated closing arrangements operable from the control position required by paragraph (h);

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: means shall be provided, at a location outside the machinery spaces where they will be accessible in the event of fire, for stopping ventilation fans serving such spaces, forced draught fans, induced draught fans, oil fuel transfer and pressure pumps and other oil fuel pumps;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: means shall be provided, at a location outside the machinery spaces where they will be accessible in the event of a fire, for closing all machinery space ventilators, annular spaces around funnels and other openings to such spaces;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: the controls required by paragraphs (b), (c), (f) and (g) shall, together with the oil fuel installation controls required by regulation 114(14) and the fixed fire extinguishing system controls required by regulation 7, 14 or 15 of the Merchant Shipping (Safety) (Fire Appliances) (Ships Built On or After 25 May 1980 but Before 1 September 1984) Regulations (Cap. 369 sub. leg. X), be located at one control position where they will be available in the event of fire. The Director may permit such controls to be grouped in more than one control position if he is satisfied that the arrangements provided are not less effective;

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: any machinery space of Category A which is accessible from an adjacent shaft tunnel shall be provided with a light-weight steel fire-screen door in addition to any watertight door. The fire-screen door shall be operable from each side and shall be located at the shaft tunnel side of the bulkhead.

section.name: s66A
section.heading: Fire protection in case of repairs, alterations, modifications, etc.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subregulation (2), every ship to which this Part applies shall, when undergoing repairs, alterations or modifications, or outfitting related thereto, comply with the following requirements—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the following surfaces shall be such that a Class 1 surface spread of flame will not be exceeded— (E.R. 3 of 2022)

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: exposed surfaces in corridors and stairway enclosures; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.leadIn: surfaces of the following within all accommodation spaces, service spaces and control stations—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: bulkheads, wall and ceiling lining; and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: concealed or inaccessible spaces;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: within accommodation spaces, service spaces, control stations and machinery spaces, all ceilings, linings, draught stops and insulating materials shall be of non-combustible materials except in respect of— (E.R. 3 of 2022)

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: mail rooms and baggage rooms;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: materials used to insulate refrigerated compartments;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: materials used to insulate valves associated with hot and cold service systems provided that their exposed surfaces are such that a Class 1 surface spread of flame will not be exceeded; and

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: vapour barriers and adhesives used in conjunction with insulating materials, if their exposed surfaces are such that a Class 1 surface spread of flame will not be exceeded;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in spaces where penetration of oil products is possible, the exposed surface of insulation shall be impervious to oil or oil vapours;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: within accommodation spaces, service spaces and control stations— (E.R. 3 of 2022)

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: electric space heaters shall be fixed in position and shall be so constructed as to reduce risk of fire to a minimum, and no such heater shall be fitted with an element so exposed that clothing, curtains or similar materials can be scorched or set on fire by heat from the element; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: cellulose-nitrate film shall not be used for cinematograph installations.

subsection.content: Where any ship to which this Part applies undergoes repairs, alterations or modifications, or outfitting related thereto, which involves the replacement of materials of 50 tonnes or above, other than that required by regulation 56(3A), 57(6A), (6B), (6C) or (9), 59(13) or (14), 63(1A), 64(1)(f), 65(e), 89(2A), (2B), (2C) or (4), 92(2) or (3), 95A, 97(3) or (4), 101A, 128(5A) or 131(3), the ship shall comply in all respects with the provisions of the Merchant Shipping (Safety) (Fire Protection) (Ships Built On or After 1 September 1984) Regulations (Cap. 369 sub. leg. Y) to the same extent and in the same manner as if the ship were a ship constructed on or after 1 October 1994, and the provisions of these regulations shall cease to apply to the ship.

part.name: P5A
part.heading: Fire Protection—New Passenger Ships Carrying not more than 36 Passengers

section.name: s67
section.heading: Application of Part VA
section.content: This Part applies to new passenger ships of carrying not more than 36 passengers.

section.name: s68
section.heading: Passenger ships carrying not more than 36 passengers
section.content: Every ship to which this Part applies, being a ship carrying not more than 36 passengers shall comply with regulation 52 except that any reference to steel or other equivalent material, shall mean that the fire integrity and insulation standards of the structure shall be in accordance with Table 1 and Table 2 of regulation 71.

section.name: s69
section.heading: Main vertical zones and horizontal zones

subsection.content: The hull, superstructure and deckhouses in the way of accommodation and service spaces of every ship to which this Part applies shall be subdivided by bulkheads consisting of “A” Class divisions into main vertical zones. The mean length of each zone on any one deck above the bulkhead deck shall not in general exceed 40 metres. Steps and recesses shall be kept to a minimum, but any which are necessary shall consist of “A” Class divisions. These divisions shall have insulation values in accordance with Table 1 and Table 2 of regulation 71, except that where insulation values of “B-0” and “C” appear in Table 1 the value of “A-0” shall be substituted.

Any portions of such divisions which extend above the bulkhead deck shall, whenever possible, be in line with watertight subdivision bulkheads situated immediately below the bulkhead deck and shall extend from deck to deck and to the ship’s shell and, in the case of a deckhouse, to the external plating thereof.

Where a main vertical zone is subdivided by horizontal “A” Class divisions into horizontal zones for the purpose of providing an appropriate barrier between sprinklered and non-sprinklered zones of the ship, the divisions shall extend between adjacent main vertical zone bulkheads and to the shell or exterior boundaries of the ship and shall be insulated in accordance with the fire insulation and integrity values given in Table 2 of regulation 71.

content.leadIn: In ships designed for special purposes, such as car or train services, where the provision of main vertical zone bulkheads would conflict with the purpose for which the ship is intended, the Director may allow an equivalent means for controlling and limiting a fire to be substituted:
content.proviso: Provided that in a ship with special category spaces, any such space shall comply with the applicable provisions of regulation 80 and in so far as such compliance would be inconsistent with compliance with other requirements of this Part, the requirements of regulation 80 shall prevail.

section.name: s70
section.heading: Bulkheads within a main vertical zone

subsection.content: Every bulkhead within the accommodation spaces or service spaces of every ship to which this Part applies, not being a bulkhead required by these regulations to consist of an “A” Class division, shall consist of a “B” Class or a “C” Class division as prescribed in Table 1 and Table 2 of regulation 71. All such divisions may be faced with combustible materials in accordance with the provisions of regulation 77.

subsection.leadIn: All corridor bulkheads where not required to be “A” Class, shall be “B” Class divisions, which shall extend from deck to deck except—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: when continuous “B” Class ceilings and/or linings are fitted on both sides of the bulkhead, the portion of the bulkhead behind the continuous ceiling or lining shall be of a material which in thickness and composition meets the requirements of “B” Class divisions, but which is required to meet “B” Class fire integrity standards only so far as is, with regard to a particular case, reasonable and practicable in the opinion of the Director; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a ship protected by an automatic sprinkler system complying with the provisions of Schedule 11 to the Merchant Shipping (Safety) (Fire Appliances) (Ships Built On or After 25 May 1980 but Before 1 September 1984) Regulations (Cap. 369 sub. leg. X), a corridor bulkhead of “B” Class integrity may terminate at a ceiling in the corridor, provided that such a ceiling is of a material which, in thickness and composition, is acceptable in the construction of “B” Class divisions. Notwithstanding the requirements of regulation 71, such bulkheads and ceilings are required to meet “B” Class fire integrity standards only as far as is, with regard to a particular case, reasonable and practicable in the opinion of the Director. All doors and frames in such bulkheads shall be of non-combustible materials and shall be constructed and erected so as to provide fire resistance which the Director is satisfied is adequate. (E.R. 3 of 2022)

subsection.content: Every bulkhead required to be a “B” Class division, except a corridor bulkhead, shall extend from deck to deck and to the shell or other boundaries unless continuous “B” Class ceilings and/or linings are fitted on both sides of the bulkhead, in which case the bulkhead may terminate at the continuous ceiling or lining.

section.name: s71
section.heading: Fire integrity of bulkheads and decks

subsection.content: In addition to complying with the specific provisions for fire integrity of bulkheads and decks of these regulations, the minimum fire integrity of bulkheads and decks shall be as prescribed in subregulations (2) to (4) and Table 1 and Table 2 of this regulation.

Where, due to any particular structural arrangement in the ship, there may be doubt in determining from the Tables the minimum fire integrity and insulation standard of any division, such standard shall be determined to the satisfaction of the Director.

paragraph.name: b

paragraph.name: d

X), or between such zones neither of which is so protected the higher of the 2 values given in the Tables shall apply; (E.R. 3 of 2022)

X), or between such zones both of which are so protected, the lesser of the 2 values given in the Tables shall apply. Where a sprinklered zone and a non-sprinklered zone meet within accommodation and service spaces, the higher of the 2 values given in the Tables shall apply to the division between the zones; (E.R. 3 of 2022)

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: where spaces are of the same numerical category and superscription “1” is specified a bulkhead or deck of the rating shown in the Tables is only required when the adjacent spaces are for a different purpose, so that in category (9A) a galley next to a galley does not require a bulkhead, but a galley next to a paint room requires an “A-0” bulkhead;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: bulkheads separating the wheelhouse and chartroom from each other may be “B-0” rating;

paragraph.name: h

paragraph.name: i

For the application of regulation 69(1) an asterisk where appearing in Table 2, except categories (8A) and (10A), shall be read as “A-0”.

subsection.content: Continuous “B” Class ceilings or linings, in association with the relevant decks or bulkheads, may be accepted as contributing, wholly or in part, to the required insulation and integrity of a division.

section.name: s72
section.heading: Protection of stairways and lifts in accommodation and service spaces

subsection.leadIn: All stairways shall be of steel frame construction except where the Director may approve the use of other equivalent material, and shall be within enclosures formed of “A” Class divisions, except that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a stairway connecting only 2 decks need not be enclosed on both decks provided the integrity of the deck is maintained by proper bulkheads or doors at one between-deck. When a stairway is closed at one between-deck space, the stairway enclosure shall have the same integrity standard as is required by Table 2 of regulation 71 for the deck which separates the between-deck spaces; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: stairways may be fitted in the open in a public space provided they lie wholly within such public space.

subsection.content: Every opening in a stairway enclosure shall be provided with a means of closure which shall be permanently attached thereto.

Every stairway enclosure shall have direct communication with the corridors and be of sufficient area to prevent congestion having regard to the number of persons likely to use them in an emergency. In so far as practicable, stairway enclosures shall not give direct access to cabins, service lockers or other enclosed spaces containing combustibles in which a fire is likely to originate.

Every lift trunk shall be so fitted as to prevent the passage of smoke and flame from one between-deck to another and shall be provided with means of closing so as to permit the control of draught and smoke.

Where an “A” Class division is pierced for the passage of electric cables, pipes, trunks, girders or beams or for other purposes, the arrangements shall be such that the effectiveness of the division in resisting fire is not thereby impaired except as provided in subregulation (7).

Where of necessity, a ventilation duct passes through a main vertical zone bulkhead, an automatic closing fire damper shall be fitted adjacent to the bulkhead. The damper shall also be capable of being manually closed from each side of the bulkhead. The operating position shall be readily accessible and be marked in red light-reflecting colour. The duct between the bulkhead and the damper shall be of steel or other equivalent material and, if necessary, be insulated to a standard such as to comply with subregulation (1). The damper shall be fitted with a visible indicator at each operating position showing whether the damper is in the open or shut position.

Except for hatches between special category spaces within a single horizontal zone or between cargo spaces or stores or baggage spaces, and between such spaces and the weather decks, all openings shall be provided with a permanently attached means of closing which shall be at least as effective for resisting fire as the division in which it is fitted.

Every door and door frame in an “A” Class division shall be constructed of steel or other equivalent material and the means of securing it when closed shall provide resistance to fire as well as to the passage of smoke and flame, as far as practicable, equivalent to that of the bulkheads in which the doors are situated: provided that a watertight door shall not be required to be insulated.
Any door in such a division shall be so constructed that it can be opened and closed by one person from either side of the division.

Every door, in a division constructed in compliance with regulations 69(1) and 72(1), except a watertight door or one which is normally locked, shall be self-closing and capable of closing against an adverse inclination of up to 3 1/2o. The speed of door closure shall be controlled so as to prevent undue danger to personnel. All such doors which are held in the open position shall be capable of release from a control station, either simultaneously or in groups, and also individually from a position at the door. The release mechanism shall be so designed that the door will automatically close in the event of disruption of the control system, except that this requirement shall not apply to approved watertight doors. Hold-back hooks, not subject to control station release, are not permitted.

Where a space is protected by an automatic sprinkler system complying with the provisions of Schedule 11 to the Merchant Shipping (Safety) (Fire Appliances) (Ships Built On or After 25 May 1980 but Before 1 September 1984) Regulations (Cap. 369 sub. leg. X) or fitted with a continuous “B” Class ceiling, the closing of openings in decks not forming steps in main vertical zones nor bounding horizontal zones shall be closed reasonably tight and such decks shall meet the “A” Class integrity requirements in so far as is, as regards a particular case, reasonable and practicable in the opinion of the Director. (E.R. 3 of 2022)

The requirements for “A” Class integrity of the outer boundaries of a ship shall not apply to glass partitions, windows and sidescuttles, subject to the requirements of regulation 76. The requirements for “A” Class integrity shall not apply to exterior doors in superstructures and deckhouses, except that doors opening onto lifeboat and liferaft handling and embarkation areas shall be of such construction as to protect these areas from a space having a potential fire hazard.

Where a “B” Class division is pierced for the passage of electric cables, pipes, trunks, girders, beams, or for other purposes, the arrangements shall be such that the effectiveness of the division in resisting fire is not thereby impaired except as provided in subregulation (5).

All doors and door frames in “B” Class divisions and means of securing them shall provide a method of closure which shall have resistance to fire as far as practicable equivalent to the division, except that ventilation openings may be permitted in the lower portion of such doors. Where such opening is in or under a door the total net area of any such opening or openings shall not exceed 0.05 square metre. When such opening is cut in a door it shall be fitted with a grill made of steel. Doors shall be non-combustible.

The requirements for “B” Class integrity of the outer boundaries of a ship shall not apply to glass partitions, windows and sidescuttles. Similarly, the requirements for “B” Class integrity shall not apply to exterior doors in superstructures and deckhouses.
A door which separates a cabin from an individual interior sanitary space, such as a shower space, may be constructed of combustible materials.

subsection.leadIn: Where an automatic sprinkler system complying with the provisions of Schedule 11 to the Merchant Shipping (Safety) (Fire Appliances) (Ships Built On or After 25 May 1980 but Before 1 September 1984) Regulations (Cap. 369 sub. leg. X) is fitted— (E.R. 3 of 2022)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the closing of openings in decks need only meet the “B” Class integrity requirements in so far as is reasonable and practicable; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: openings in corridor bulkheads of “B” Class materials shall be protected in accordance with the provisions of regulation 70.

subsection.content: Wherever practicable the system of ducts leading from each ventilating fan shall be within one main vertical or horizontal zone.

Where ventilation systems penetrate decks, precautions shall be taken, in addition to those relating to the fire integrity of the decks required by regulation 73, to reduce the likelihood of smoke and hot gases passing from one between-deck space to another through the system. In addition to insulation requirements contained in this regulation, vertical ducts shall, if necessary, be insulated as required by Table 1 and Table 2 of regulation 71.
The main inlets of every air supply system and the main outlets of every air exhaust system shall be capable of being closed from external positions.
Ducts serving a stairway enclosure shall be taken from the fan room independently of other ducts in the ventilation system and shall not serve any other space.

All power ventilation of accommodation spaces, service spaces, control stations (except any alternative ventilation system which may be required under subregulation (6)) and machinery spaces shall be capable of being stopped from an easily accessible position outside the space being served. This position should not be so situated as to be cut off in the event of a fire in the spaces served. The means provided for stopping the power ventilation of the machinery spaces shall be entirely separate from the means provided for stopping the ventilation of other spaces.

There shall be provided for every control station situated below deck, other than a control station situated in the machinery space, means to ensure ventilation, visibility and freedom from smoke within it so that in the event of a fire in the ship, the equipment it contains may be operated effectively. Unless the control station is situated on, and has access to, an open deck or is provided with local closing arrangements equally effective to maintain ventilation, visibility and freedom from smoke in the event of a fire in the ship, there shall be provided at least 2 entirely separate means of supplying air to such control stations and the air inlets to these sources of supply shall be so situated that the risk of both drawing in smoke simultaneously is, as far as practicable, eliminated.

subsection.leadIn: Except in cargo spaces, ventilation ducts shall be constructed of the following materials—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: ducts not less than 0.075 square metre in sectional area and all vertical ducts serving more than a single between-deck space shall be constructed of steel or other equivalent material;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: subject to the requirements of paragraph (c) and of subregulations (8) and (9), ducts of less than 0.075 square metre in sectional area shall be constructed of non-combustible materials. Where such ducts penetrate “A” Class or “B” Class division, due regard shall be given to ensuring the fire integrity of the division;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: ducts, not in general exceeding 0.02 square metre in sectional area nor 2 metres in length, need not be non-combustible provided that the following conditions are satisfied— (E.R. 3 of 2022)

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the duct is constructed of suitable material having regard to the risk of fire;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the duct is used only at the terminal end of the ventilation system; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the duct is not located closer than 0.6 metre along its length to a penetration of an “A” Class or “B” Class division. (E.R. 3 of 2022)

subsection.leadIn: Ducts provided for the ventilation of machinery spaces of Category A, galleys or car deck spaces shall not pass through accommodation spaces, service spaces or control stations unless either—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the ducts are constructed of steel having a thickness of at least 3 millimetres and 5 millimetres for ducts the widths or diameters of which are up to and including 300 millimetres and 760 millimetres and over respectively and, in the case of such ducts, the widths or diameters of which are between 300 millimetres and 760 millimetres having a thickness to be obtained by interpolation;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: are suitably supported and stiffened;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: are fitted with automatic fire dampers close to the boundaries penetrated; and

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: are insulated to “A-60” standard from the machinery space, galley or car deck space to a point at least 5 metres beyond each fire damper; or

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the ducts are constructed, supported and stiffened in accordance with paragraph (a)(i) and (ii); and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: are insulated to “A-60” standard throughout the accommodation spaces, service spaces or control stations,

subsection.continued: except that penetrations of main zone bulkheads or decks shall comply with the requirements of regulation 73.

subsection.leadIn: Ducts providing ventilation to accommodation spaces, service spaces or control stations shall not pass through machinery spaces of Category A, galleys or car deck spaces unless either—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the ducts where they pass through a machinery space of Category A, galley or car deck space are constructed, supported and stiffened in accordance with subregulation (8)(a)(i) and (ii);

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: automatic fire dampers are fitted close to the boundaries penetrated; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the integrity of the machinery space, galley or car deck space boundaries is maintained at the penetrations; or

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the ducts where they pass through a machinery space of Category A, galley or car deck space are constructed of steel in accordance with subregulation (8)(a)(i) and (ii); and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: are insulated to “A-60” standard within the machinery space, galley or car deck space,

subsection.continued: except that penetrations of main zone bulkheads and decks shall comply with regulation 73.

subsection.leadIn: Exhaust ducts from galley ranges, where they pass through accommodation spaces containing combustible materials, shall be constructed of “A” Class divisions. Every exhaust duct shall be fitted with—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a grease trap readily removable for cleaning;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a fire damper located in the duct at the boundary of the galley;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: arrangements, operable from within the galley, for shutting off the exhaust fan; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a fixed means of extinguishing a fire within the duct.

subsection.leadIn: Where a ventilation duct of sectional area exceeding 0.02 square metre passes through an “A” Class bulkhead or deck, the opening in the bulkhead or deck shall be lined with a steel sheet sleeve unless the duct, where it passes through the bulkhead or deck, is constructed of steel. At the penetration the sleeve or duct shall comply with the following specification—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the duct or sleeve shall have a thickness of at least 3 millimetres over a length of 900 millimetres. When passing through bulkheads this length shall if possible be divided into 450 millimetres on each side of the bulkhead. The duct or sleeve shall be insulated so as to maintain the standard of fire integrity of the deck or bulkhead; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: every duct shall be fitted with a fire damper unless the Director determines otherwise. In every duct of sectional area exceeding 0.075 square metre, the fire damper shall operate automatically but it shall also be capable of being closed manually from each side of the bulkhead or deck. The operating position shall be readily accessible and be marked in red light-reflecting colour. The damper shall be fitted with a visible indicator showing whether the damper is in the open or shut position. Fire dampers are not required, however, where ducts pass through spaces surrounded by “A” Class divisions without serving those spaces, provided those ducts have the same fire integrity and insulation value as the bulkheads which they pierce.

subsection.content: Where a ventilation duct of sectional area exceeding 0.02 square metre passes through a “B” Class bulkhead, the opening shall be lined with a steel sleeve of 900 millimetres in length unless the duct, where it passes through the bulkhead, is constructed of steel. This length shall be divided, if possible, into 450 millimetres on each side of the bulkhead.

All windows and sidescuttles in bulkheads within accommodation and service spaces and control stations other than those to which the provisions of regulations 73(8) and 74(3) apply, shall be constructed so as to preserve the integrity requirements of the type of bulkheads in which they are fitted.

subsection.leadIn: Notwithstanding the requirements of the Tables at the end of regulation 71—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: all windows and sidescuttles in bulkheads separating accommodation and service spaces and control stations from weather shall be constructed with frames of steel or other suitable material. The glass shall be retained by a metal glazing bead or angle; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the fire integrity of windows facing opening or enclosed lifeboat and liferaft embarkation areas and of windows situated below such areas in such a position that their failure during a fire would impede the launching of, or embarkation into, lifeboats or liferafts shall be such that any potential fire hazard is kept to a minimum.

subsection.leadIn: Within accommodation spaces, service spaces and control stations the following provisions shall apply—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the following surfaces shall be such that a Class 1 or 2 surface spread of flame will not be exceeded— (E.R. 3 of 2022)

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: exposed surfaces in corridor, stairway enclosures, bulkheads, wall and ceiling linings; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: concealed or inaccessible spaces;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the total volume of combustible facings, mouldings, decorations and veneers shall not exceed a volume equivalent to 2.5 millimetres of veneer on the combined area of walls and ceilings. In the case of ships fitted with an automatic sprinkler system complying with the provisions of Schedule 11 to the Merchant Shipping (Safety) (Fire Appliances) (Ships Built On or After 25 May 1980 but Before 1 September 1984) Regulations (Cap. 369 sub. leg. X), the above volume may include some combustible material used for the erection of “C” Class divisions;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: veneers used on surfaces and linings to which subregulation (1)(a) applies shall not have a gross calorific potential exceeding 45 megajoules per square metre of surface area for the thickness used as measured in accordance with International Standard ISO 1716-1973(E);

paragraph.name: d
e
paragraph.content: primary deck coverings, if applied, shall be of approved material which will not readily ignite or give rise to toxic or explosive hazards at elevated temperatures;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: waste-paper receptacles shall be constructed of non-combustible materials and with solid sides and bottoms. (E.R. 3 of 2022)

subsection.leadIn: Within accommodation spaces, service spaces, control stations and machinery spaces the following requirements should be complied with—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: all ceilings, linings, draught stops and insulating materials shall be of non-combustible materials except in respect of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: mail rooms and baggage rooms;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: materials used to insulate refrigerated compartments;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: materials used to insulate valves associated with hot and cold service systems if their exposed surfaces are such that a Class 1 or 2 surface spread of flame will not be exceeded;

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: vapour barriers and adhesives used in conjunction with insulating materials if their exposed surfaces are such that a Class 1 or 2 surface spread of flame will not be exceeded; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: paints, varnishes and other finishes used on exposed interior surfaces shall not be capable of producing excessive quantities of smoke and toxic products.

subsection.leadIn: The following provisions shall apply to all parts of any ship to which this Part applies—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any pipe which penetrates an “A” Class or “B” Class division shall be of suitable material and having regard to the temperature such divisions are required to withstand;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: pipes intended for oil or other flammable liquids shall be of suitable material having regard to the risk of fire; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: overboard scuppers, sanitary discharges or other outlets close to or below the waterline shall not be of a material likely to fail in the event of fire and thereby give rise to a danger of flooding.

subsection.leadIn: The following provisions shall apply to the accommodation and service spaces, control stations, corridors and stairways of any ship to which this Part applies—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: every air space enclosed behind a ceiling, panel or lining shall be divided by close-fitting draught-stops, which shall be spaced not more than 14 metres apart and which shall be closed at each deck; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: every ceiling panel and lining shall be so constructed as to enable a fire patrol to detect any smoke originating in a concealed or inaccessible space without impairing the efficiency of the fire protection of the ship. The Director may exempt any ship from the requirements of this regulation if he is satisfied that there is no risk of fire originating in such a space.

section.name: s79
section.heading: Automatic sprinkler and fire alarm and fire detection system or automatic fire alarm and fire detection system

subsection.leadIn: In every ship to which this Part applies there shall be installed throughout each separate zone, whether vertical or horizontal, in all accommodation and service spaces and in control stations either—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an automatic sprinkler and fire alarm and fire detection system complying with the requirements specified in Schedule 11 to the Merchant Shipping (Safety) (Fire Appliances) (Ships Built On or After 25 May 1980 but Before 1 September 1984) Regulations (Cap. 369 sub. leg. X) and so arranged to protect all such spaces in the ship; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an automatic fire alarm and fire detection system complying with the requirements specified in Schedule 12 to the Merchant Shipping (Safety) (Fire Appliances) (Ships Built On or After 25 May 1980 but Before 1 September 1984) Regulations (Cap. 369 sub. leg. X) and so arranged to detect the presence or the signs of a fire and its location in any such spaces. (E.R. 3 of 2022)

subsection.leadIn: The Director may exempt any ship from the requirements of this regulation in so far as they apply to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any space which he is satisfied affords no substantial fire risk; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any control station.

subsection.leadIn: The following provisions shall apply to special category spaces, whether above or below the bulkhead deck, of any ship to which this Part applies—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: when normal main vertical zoning is not practicable in special category spaces, equivalent protection shall be obtained in such spaces by horizontal zoning and the provision of an efficient fixed fire-extinguishing system. A horizontal zone for the purpose of this regulation may include special category spaces on more than one deck provided that the overall height of the zone does not exceed 10 metres; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: all the requirements of regulations 73 and 75 as regards maintaining the integrity of vertical zones shall apply to decks and bulkheads forming the boundaries separating horizontal zones from each other and from the remainder of the ship;

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: boundary bulkheads of special category spaces shall be insulated as required for Category (11A) spaces in Table 1 and the horizontal boundaries as required for Category (11A) spaces in Table 2 of regulation 71;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: indicators shall be provided on the navigating bridge which shall indicate when any access fire door in the boundary of a special category space is closed;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: every special category space shall be fitted with a manually operated fixed pressure water-spraying system which complies with the requirements specified in Schedule 8 to the Merchant Shipping (Safety) (Fire Appliances) (Ships Built On or After 25 May 1980 but Before 1 September 1984) Regulations (Cap. 369 sub. leg. X). The Director may permit any other fixed fire-extinguishing system which he is satisfied is equally effective by full-scale test in conditions simulating a flowing petrol fire in a special category space; (E.R. 3 of 2022)

subparagraph.name: i
ii

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: every special category space shall be provided with a ventilation system capable of changing the atmosphere within such spaces at least 10 times per hour based upon the gross volume of the space. The ventilation system shall be arranged to prevent stratification of the atmosphere and the formation of gas pockets in such spaces. The ventilation system shall be separate from any other ventilation system and the master shall ensure that it shall be operated at all times when vehicles are in such spaces. Any loss or reduction of the ventilation system capacity shall be indicated on the navigating bridge. The outlet from any exhaust ventilation duct shall be sited in a safe position having regard to possible sources of ignition.

text.b: Additional requirements applicable only to special category spaces above the bulkhead deck

subsection.text: The following provisions shall apply additionally to those in subregulation (1) to special category spaces above the bulkhead deck of any ship to which this Part applies—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to ensure the clearance of water accumulating on the deck or decks consequent on the operation of the fixed pressure water-spraying system, scuppers shall be fitted so as to ensure that such water is rapidly discharged directly overboard; and

text.b: Precautions against ignition of flammable vapours

content.leadIn: electrical equipment, wiring and other equipment capable of igniting flammable vapours shall not be installed less than 450 millimetres above any deck on which vapours may accumulate:
content.proviso: Provided that electrical equipment and wiring may be installed below such level and within the ventilation trunks, if it is essential for the safe operation of the ship, provided that the equipment is of a type suitable for use in an explosive petrol vapour and air mixture. Electrical equipment installed more than 450 millimetres above any deck on which vapours may accumulate shall be enclosed and protected to prevent discharge of sparks.

text.b: Additional requirements applicable only to special category spaces below the bulkhead deck

subsection.leadIn: The following provisions shall apply in addition to subregulation (1) as regards special category spaces below the bulkhead deck of any ship to which this Part applies—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: adequate bilge pumping and drainage facilities shall be provided to ensure the clearance of water from the deck or tank top following the operation of the fixed pressure water-spraying system. Where the capacity of the bilge pumps is insufficient to ensure the clearance of the water, additional bilge pumping capacity shall be provided; and

text.b: Precautions against ignition of flammable vapours

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: electrical equipment and wiring within such spaces and in ventilation trunks serving such spaces shall be of a type suitable for use in an explosive petrol vapour and air mixture. Other equipment which may constitute a source of ignition of flammable vapours shall not be fitted.

section.name: s81
section.heading: Protection of cargo spaces, other than special category spaces, intended for the carriage of motor vehicles with fuel in their tanks for their own propulsion
section.leadIn: In every ship to which this Part applies, the following provisions shall apply to any cargo space, other than special category spaces, containing motor vehicles with fuel in their tanks for their own propulsion—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an automatic fire alarm and fire detection system complying with the requirements specified in Schedule 12 to the Merchant Shipping (Safety) (Fire Appliances) (Ships Built On or After 25 May 1980 but Before 1 September 1984) Regulations (Cap. 369 sub. leg. X) shall be provided; (E.R. 3 of 2022)

paragraph.name: b
